elements.content: Incorporation of the same ligand into three different aluminum phenylenediphosphonates (Al­(H2O)­(O3PC6H4PO3H) (1), Al4(H2O)2­(O3PC6H4PO3)3 (2), and Al4(H2O)4­(O3PC6H4PO3)2.84­(OH)0.64 (3)) was accomplished by varying the synthetic conditions. The compounds have different sorption properties; however, all exhibit reversible dehydration behavior. The structures of the hydrated and dehydrated phases were determined from powder X-ray diffraction data. Compounds 2 and 3 were found to be microporous, while compound 1 was found to be nonporous. The stability of the dehydrated phase and the resulting porosity was found to be influenced by the change in the structure upon loss of water.

The compounds have different sorption properties; however, all exhibit reversible dehydration behavior. elements.content: Solid state transitions of three aluminum phenylenediphosphonates were studied by NMR and in situ X-ray diffraction. The change in Al-coordination sphere due to loss of water influenced the pore structure and thus the porosity of the material. The diversity in compounds that were obtained by varying the synthetic procedure demonstrates that with careful synthetic control new compounds can be developed.

elements.content: Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), built from ligands containing phosphonic acids rather than carboxylates, have been suggested; however, obtaining highly crystalline porous materials is challenging. Phosphonic acids strongly coordinate to a wide range of metals and show both chemical and high thermal stability, which makes them advantageous over carboxylate analogues. Highly crystalline, open-framework metal phosphonates have been recently reported. These materials do not have the traditional pillar architecture that is generally found for metal phosphonates. Unlike most MOFs with isolated metal clusters or atoms as secondary building units, infinite units are favored due to the tetrahedral geometry of the phosphonate group. The pillared architecture is formed by closely packed pillars which link the inorganic layers, resulting in nonporous materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), built from ligands containing phosphonic acids rather than carboxylates, have been suggested; however, obtaining highly crystalline porous materials is challenging. Phosphonic acids strongly coordinate to a wide range of metals and show both chemical and high thermal stability, which makes them advantageous over carboxylate analogues. Highly crystalline, open-framework metal phosphonates have been recently reported. These materials do not have the traditional pillar architecture that is generally found for metal phosphonates. Unlike most MOFs with isolated metal clusters or atoms as secondary building units, infinite units are favored due to the tetrahedral geometry of the phosphonate group. The pillared architecture is formed by closely packed pillars which link the inorganic layers, resulting in nonporous materials.

elements.content: The structures of the “non-traditional” metal phosphonates result from unique aspects of the ligands that are used. The heterofunctional ligands N,N′-piperazinebis-(methylenephosphonic acid) and N,N,N′-4,4′-bipiperidinebis­(methylenephosphonic acid)) were used to synthesize isoreticular structures where the pore size increased from 0.9 to 1.8 nm. The protonated amino group balanced the overall charge. The materials have permanent porosity and coordinatively unsaturated metal sites upon loss of coordinated water, which is extremely important for gas adsorption applications.

The protonated amino group balanced the overall charge. The materials have permanent porosity and coordinatively unsaturated metal sites upon loss of coordinated water, which is extremely important for gas adsorption applications.

elements.content: Several porous structures have been published using phosphonate esters in the initial synthesis. These materials involve phenylenediphosphonate esters. The use of this ligand in the acid form has resulted in many pillared architectures. However, by eliminating use of one phosphonate oxygen atom by careful synthetic control, the ligand acts in a manner similar to a carboxylic acid group used in MOFs and does not form the pillared architecture.

elements.content: The continuous nucleation of the inorganic structure could also be prevented by a small ligand coordinating to the metal ion, which does not have additional coordinating groups. These ligands could range from water molecules, fluoride ions, phosphites, to amines.

elements.content: The metal ions used to form the metal phosphonate influences the structure formed by both the resulting metal coordination and geometry. For divalent and trivalent metal ions, coordination geometries with specific ligands are well-known. Versatility in both metal coordination and geometry can be seen with aluminum ions in AlMePO, where it can range from tetrahedral through pentacoordinate to octahedral. Varying metal coordination and geometry make the number of materials that can be synthesized extensive.

elements.content: Reported herein are three highly crystalline aluminum phenylenediphosphonates Al­(H2O)­(O3PC6H4PO3H), Al4(H2O)2­(O3PC6H4PO3)3, and Al4(H2O)4­(O3PC6H4PO3)2.84­(OH)0.64 that exhibit reversible dehydration behavior, which has a dramatic influence on permanent porosity of the material. The stability of the dehydrated phase is a result of the change in the structure, and in some cases there are coordinatively unsaturated metal sites.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

All purchased reagents were used with no further purification. The ligands 4,4-phenylenediphosphonic acid (H4PDPA) was prepared by an adapted literature procedure. The aluminum source, bayerite (Al(OH)3), was also prepared according to the literature procedure.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction was carried out with 4 mL of ddi water and 2.5 mL of conc. HCl, which was added to a 12 mL capacity PTFE-lined pressure vessel containing 0.111 g (1.42 mmol) of bayerite and 0.321 g (1.34 mmol) of H4PDPA. The sealed reaction vessel was then heated to 160 °C for 5 days. The resulting white powder was filtered, washed with ddi water and acetone, and then air-dried. Yield: 0.262 g. Elemental analysis (%) and microprobe Al/P ratio calc: C 25.73, H 2.52, P/Al ratio 2.00. Exp: C 25.6, H 2.5, P/Al ratio 1.99.

elements.content: Elemental analysis for carbon, nitrogen, and hydrogen (C, N, and H) were performed by Atlantic Microlab, Inc. The Al:P ratio was determined on a four spectrometer Ceca SX50 electron microprobe using a PGT energy-dispersive X-ray system at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV at a beam current of 20 nA. All quantitative work employed wavelength-dispersive spectrometers (WDS). Analyses were carried out after standardization using very well characterized compounds or pure elements. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a T.A. Instrument TGA Q-500. The samples were heated from 30 to 1000 °C using a heating rate of 10 °C/min with a 90/10 air/N2 flow. A Bruker Avance 400 Solids NMR spectrometer equipped by a standard 7, MAS probe head was used to acquire solid state 27Al­{1H} and 31P­{1H} MAS NMR operating at a 5 kHz spinning rate for both 27Al­{1H} and 31P­{1H} with 0 ppm for [Al­(H2O)6]3+ and H3PO4 as external chemical shift standards. N2 sorption–desorption isotherms were obtained on a Quantachrome Autosorb-6 instrument at liquid nitrogen temperature. Compound 1 was dried in the oven for 12 h at 150 °C and then degassed under a vacuum at 200 °C for 20 h on a Quantachrome degasser. All other compounds were dried in an oven overnight at 150 °C and then degassed under a vacuum at 180–210 °C for 20 h Quantachrome degasser. Surface areas were derived from the isotherms by the BET and t-plot methods. Some powder patterns were obtained on the Bruker D8-Focus Bragg–Brentano X-ray powder diffractometer operating with Cu radiation (1.542 Å).

Data collection was performed with a PerkinElmer flat panel area detector (XRD 1621 CN3-EHS) over the angular range 1–25° 2θ.
elements.clean_text:
In Situ X-ray Diffraction Hydration Study

All synchrotron powder diffraction data for the in situ X-ray diffraction hydration experiments were recorded on 1-BM-C at Advance Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory (Argonne, USA) with an average beamline wavelength of 0.6124 Å. Data collection was performed with a PerkinElmer flat panel area detector (XRD 1621 CN3-EHS) over the angular range 1-25° 2θ.

elements.content: Samples were loaded in a kapton capillary (0.9 mm diameter), which was attached to the flow-cell setup for in situ synchrotron PXRD measurements. The samples were heated with a heating rate of 3 K min–1 under a He-gas flow to reach the target temperature and then cooled down to 298 K. To rehydrate the materials at 298 K, the samples were exposed to water vapor with a He-gas flow.

elements.content: Samples were loaded in kapton capillaries (0.9 mm diameter) and mounted on bases provided by the Advance Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory. The samples were mailed to APS for analysis. High resolution synchrotron powder diffraction data were collected using beamline 11-BM with an average wavelength of 0.41625 Å for all compounds. Two platinum-striped collimating mirrors and a double-crystal Si(111) monochromator are used for the X-ray optics. The data points were collected at room temperature with a step size of 0.001° 2θ and scan speed of 0.01 o/s. Data are collected while continually scanning the diffractometer 2θ arm. High resolution and short collection time are obtained by using a unique 12-element Si (111) crystal analyzer/detector. For quick and precise sample exchange, a Mitsubishi robotic arm is used to mount and dismount samples on the diffractometer. Samples 1, 1d, and 2 were collected at 295 K. Additional steps were taken for sample 2d, the dehydrated phase of 2. Sample 2d was heated at 450 K for 1 h prior to data collection and then collected at 450 K.
elements.clean_text:
High Resolution Synchrotron PXRD

Samples were loaded in kapton capillaries (0.9 mm diameter) and mounted on bases provided by the Advance Photon Source (APS), Argonne National Laboratory. The samples were mailed to APS for analysis. High resolution synchrotron powder diffraction data were collected using beamline 11-BM with an average wavelength of 0.41625 Å for all compounds. Two platinum-striped collimating mirrors and a double-crystal Si(111) monochromator are used for the X-ray optics. The data points were collected at room temperature with a step size of 0.001° 2θ and scan speed of 0.01 o/s. Data are collected while continually scanning the diffractometer 2θ arm. High resolution and short collection time are obtained by using a unique 12-element Si (111) crystal analyzer/detector. For quick and precise sample exchange, a Mitsubishi robotic arm is used to mount and dismount samples on the diffractometer. Samples 1, 1d, and 2 were collected at 295 K. Additional steps were taken for sample 2d, the dehydrated phase of 2. Sample 2d was heated at 450 K for 1 h prior to data collection and then collected at 450 K.

elements.content: A set of approximately 20 Bragg peaks were used by the indexing procedure in the TOPAS program to determine the unit cell. Evaluation of the unit cell and all possible space groups were analyzed by the “profile matching mode” (Le Bail decomposition) with the TOPAS program. Analysis for systematic absences and best profile matching led to the correct space groups. The initial models for compounds 1, 1d, and 2 were found by the charge flipping method in the TOPAS program. This method was unsuccessful for compound 2d; therefore, the initial model was found by direct space methods in the FOX program. The initial model was found using the following scattering unit, Al2(O3PC6PO3)­(O3PC3). The parallel tempering algorithm was used by the global optimization procedure. The structure and geometry of organic ligands in the initial models were corrected to reasonable values using the SHELXTL suite.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Determination

A set of approximately 20 Bragg peaks were used by the indexing procedure in the TOPAS program to determine the unit cell. Evaluation of the unit cell and all possible space groups were analyzed by the "profile matching mode" (Le Bail decomposition) with the TOPAS program. Analysis for systematic absences and best profile matching led to the correct space groups. The initial models for compounds 1, 1d, and 2 were found by the charge flipping method in the TOPAS program. This method was unsuccessful for compound 2d; therefore, the initial model was found by direct space methods in the FOX program. The initial model was found using the following scattering unit, Al2(O3PC6PO3)(O3PC3). The parallel tempering algorithm was used by the global optimization procedure. The structure and geometry of organic ligands in the initial models were corrected to reasonable values using the SHELXTL suite.

elements.content: The high resolution synchrotron PXRD data were used in the Le Bail decomposition to refine the unit cell and profile parameters in JANA2006. The background was defined using either 20 Legendre or Chebyshev polynomials. The background term 1/x was used for compounds 1 and 2. Additionally for compound 2, an anisotropic strain broadening term was applied. The peak shape profiles were defined by a pseudo-Voigt function. The geometrical parameters were restrained to reasonable values. A Rietveld refinement was successful for compounds 1–2d. Additional information regarding the Rietveld refinements of compounds 1–2d is given in the . The crystallographic and refinement parameters are given in Table . H atoms were geometrically placed and fixed before the final refinement. Rietveld fits are given in (Figures S1–4).

Compounds 2 and 2d super-sub cell relationship: a for 2 is ∼2c for 2d.

The structure of compound 1 was determined from PXRD data (Figure ). Compound 1, Al­(H2O)­(O3PC6H4PO3H), crystallized in the monoclinic P21 /c space group, and the asymmetric unit consists of one Al­(III) ion, one water molecule, and one HPDPA molecule. The inorganic layer in the (b,c)-plane is built from AlO6 octahedra bridged together by O–P–O bridges to form 8- and 16-member rings (Figure , right). Oxygen atoms from five distinct phosphonate moieties and one water molecule form the AlO6 octahedron. The free space in the 16-member ring is occupied by two symmetry dependent water molecules that protrude into the ring. The 2D layer described so far is interlinked by the HPDPA molecule along the [100] direction to form a 3D framework (Figure , left). One proton remains on the phosphonate group for charge balance. The compound could be described as an I2O1 framework using the notation I m O n where m and n stand for the dimensionality of the inorganic and organic connectivity, respectively. Interestingly, the inorganic layer is similar to metal ethylenediphosphonates with the formula M­(III)­(H2O)­(O3P­(CH2)2PO3H) (M = Fe, Ga, Al). The pendent protonated oxygen found in both of these systems is relatively rare for iron/aluminuim/gallium structures.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compounds 1 and 1d 

The structure of compound 1 was determined from PXRD data (Figure ). Compound 1, Al(H2O)(O3PC6H4PO3H), crystallized in the monoclinic P21 /c space group, and the asymmetric unit consists of one Al(III) ion, one water molecule, and one HPDPA molecule. The inorganic layer in the (b,c)-plane is built from AlO6 octahedra bridged together by O-P-O bridges to form 8- and 16-member rings (Figure , right). Oxygen atoms from five distinct phosphonate moieties and one water molecule form the AlO6 octahedron. The free space in the 16-member ring is occupied by two symmetry dependent water molecules that protrude into the ring. The 2D layer described so far is interlinked by the HPDPA molecule along the [100] direction to form a 3D framework (Figure , left). One proton remains on the phosphonate group for charge balance. The compound could be described as an I2O1 framework using the notation I m O n  where m and n stand for the dimensionality of the inorganic and organic connectivity, respectively. Interestingly, the inorganic layer is similar to metal ethylenediphosphonates with the formula M(III)(H2O)(O3P(CH2)2PO3H) (M = Fe, Ga, Al). The pendent protonated oxygen found in both of these systems is relatively rare for iron/aluminuim/gallium structures.

elements.content: Upon dehydration of compound 1, the material retained the I2O1 framework and converted to AlO3PC6H4PO3H (1d) (Figure ). In compound 1, the aluminum atom has octahedral geometry but with loss of a water molecule the geometry of the aluminum atom would then be square pyramidal without rearrangement of the inorganic framework. The geometry of the aluminum atom was determined to be trigonal bipyrmidal; therefore rearrangement of the inorganic framework occurred and can be clearly seen in Figure . The monoclinic space group P21 /c was determined for compound 1d; however changes in the structure caused by dehydration can be described by a comparison of the crystallographic data for compound 1 and 1d. The a-axis is slightly shortened upon dehydration (Table ), but this does not significantly affect the inorganic interlayer distance (7.266 and 7.296 Å for 1 and 1d respectively). Viewed down the b-axis the crystal structures for 1 and 1d have similar pillared structures where phenylenediphosphonate bridges the inorganic layers. The b-axis is shortened and has an effect on the inorganic layer, lying in the (b, c) plane. As the geometry transforms from octahedral to trigonal pyramidal (Figure ), the b-axis is shortened and the free space in the 8- and 16-member ring decreases: (a, b = 4.5, 8.2 Å and 3.5, 8.2 Å for compound 1 and 1d, respectively, Figure ). Thus, dehydration causes a change in the aluminum geometry, which results in a decrease in both a- and b-axis and a decrease in volume of the unit cell (loss of 62 Å3).

The geometry of the aluminum atom was determined to be trigonal bipyrmidal; therefore rearrangement of the inorganic framework occurred and can be clearly seen in Figure . The monoclinic space group P21 /c was determined for compound 1d; however changes in the structure caused by dehydration can be described by a comparison of the crystallographic data for compound 1 and 1d. The a-axis is slightly shortened upon dehydration (Table ), but this does not significantly affect the inorganic interlayer distance (7.266 and 7.296 Å for 1 and 1d respectively). Viewed down the b-axis the crystal structures for 1 and 1d have similar pillared structures where phenylenediphosphonate bridges the inorganic layers. The b-axis is shortened and has an effect on the inorganic layer, lying in the (b, c) plane. As the geometry transforms from octahedral to trigonal pyramidal (Figure ), the b-axis is shortened and the free space in the 8- and 16-member ring decreases: (a, b = 4.5, 8.2 Å and 3.5, 8.2 Å for compound 1 and 1d, respectively, Figure ). Thus, dehydration causes a change in the aluminum geometry, which results in a decrease in both a- and b-axis and a decrease in volume of the unit cell (loss of 62 Å3).

elements.content: The structure of compound 2 has been determined from PXRD data (Figure ). Compound 2 crystallized in the monoclinic C2/m space group, and the asymmetric unit consists of two Al­(III) ions, one and a half PDPA molecules, and one water molecule. The aluminum species, AlO4 and AlO6, are coordinated to four or five distinct oxygen phosponate atoms, respectively, with the AlO6 group bonding to an additional water molecule. The inorganic layer in the (b,c) plane is built from double metal chains bridged in the [001] direction forming 12-member rings (Figure , right). The double metal chain is built from columns of AlO6 octrahedra and AlO4 tetrahedra running in the [010] direction. The inorganic layers are bridged by two distinct alternating pillared layers in the [100] direction. The first pillared layer is a traditional layer where the pillars are spaced close together to form a densely packed structure. The second pillared layer is a “non-traditional” layer, where the pillars are spaced apart such that channels are formed. The water molecule coordinated to the AlO6 can be clearly seen to protrude into the interlayer spacing of these channels. On the basis of elemental analysis and TGA (10.4 wt % water), additional water may be present within the pores but could not be determined from the PXRD data. The formula Al4(H2O)2­(O3PC6H4PO3)3­(H2O)4 better represents both the elemental and TGA data. The structure could be described as an I2O1 framework.

elements.content: Upon dehydration of compound 2, the compound was converted to Al4(O3PC6H4PO3)3 (2d) with the octahedral aluminum atom losing one coordinated water molecule (Figure ). The loss of water did not change the I2O1 framework, but differences in the structures were found. The triclinic P1̅ space group was determined with the asymmetric unit consisting of one and a half PDPA molecules, a tetrahedral aluminum atom (AlO4), and a five-coordinate aluminum atom (AlO5). Unit cells of compound 2 and 2d have a super-sub cell relationship such that compound 2 has twice the volume of 2d. The a axis for compound 2 is approximately 2xc for compound 2d. The geometry of the AlO5 was determined to be distorted square pyramidal. To accommodate the new metal geometry, the phosphonate groups rotate from the original positions altering the inorganic layer (Figure ). The distance between the double metal chains which build the inorganic layer increased from 8.381 to 8.594 Å upon loss of water. This increases the width of the channels. However, along the [010] direction, there is no significant change in the structure (Al···Al distance: 5.004 and 4.971 Å for 2 and 2d).

elements.content: Although in reactions 1–3 the same ligand, H4PDPA, was used, three different PXRD patterns were recorded (Figure ). A decrease in crystallinity is observed in changing the source of aluminum from bayerite to aluminum chloride; however, other factors may play a role as well, such as solubility and pH. Similar d-spacings were found when the only solvent was changed from water for 2, to a mixture of water/acetone for 3. However, other differences are seen in the PXRD patterns of compounds 2 and 3 indicating different structures were formed from the two different solvent systems. The crystal structure for 3 could not be obtained due to the poor powder crystallinity, but continuing efforts are being made to determine the structure. Differences can be seen in the PXRD patterns for 3 and its dehydrated phase (3d) ().

elements.content: For reactions 1 and 2, a change in the reaction temperature resulted in phase changes in the compounds (Figures and ). For both reactions two phases were obtained: one at low temperature and one at high temperature. The low temperature phase for reaction 1 was not isolated. Interestingly, the low temperature phase for reaction 2 resulted in compound 1 except it is less crystalline (). It is interesting that different reaction conditions resulted in the same material. Similar behavior would be expected for compounds 2 and 3, which differ only in the solvent systems. However, for reaction 3 no phase change occurred with a change in reaction temperature; rather an increase in reaction temperature led to an increase in crystallinity (). Solid state NMR also suggested similar structures ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Effects

For reactions 1 and 2, a change in the reaction temperature resulted in phase changes in the compounds (Figures  and ). For both reactions two phases were obtained: one at low temperature and one at high temperature. The low temperature phase for reaction 1 was not isolated. Interestingly, the low temperature phase for reaction 2 resulted in compound 1 except it is less crystalline (). It is interesting that different reaction conditions resulted in the same material. Similar behavior would be expected for compounds 2 and 3, which differ only in the solvent systems. However, for reaction 3 no phase change occurred with a change in reaction temperature; rather an increase in reaction temperature led to an increase in crystallinity (). Solid state NMR also suggested similar structures ().

elements.content: Solid state 27Al­{1H} and 31P­{1H} NMR studies reveal differences in the structures for compounds 1–3 (Figure ). The 27Al­{1H} NMR spectra show relatively broad peaks for compounds 1–3 (−24.3 to −29.6 ppm, respectively) which are characteristic for aluminum sites with octahedral oxygen environments. The line shapes are characteristic for quadrupolar interaction. Additionally, less broad peaks in the region 38–39 ppm are observed for compounds 2 and 3, a characteristic for aluminum sites with tetrahedral oxygen environments. The 31P­{1H} NMR spectra show multiple peaks in the range of 4.5 to −10 ppm that are characteristic of phosphonates. Peaks in the region −7 to −10 ppm region for compound 2 do not appear in the 31P­{1H} NMR spectra for 3, although both have four- and six-coordinate aluminum atoms. Considering this and the PXRD data three different compounds have been synthesized using the ligand H4PDPA.

elements.content: The thermogravimetric analysis data differs for compounds 1–3 (Figure ). Compound 1 has a three-step weight loss. The first weight loss occurs at ∼180 °C and is attributed to coordinated water molecules. The structure of the dehydrated phase was determined (1d) and is stable up to ∼440 °C, where a small weight loss occurs, after which decomposition of the material occurs at 740 °C. The second weight loss may involve the loss of the acidic proton. Compound 2 has one weight loss step before decomposition (515 °C) and occurs below 100 °C. It is attributed to loss of water molecules, and the resultant structure was determined (2d). Compound 3 has two weight losses before decomposition (515 °C). The first is below 100 °C and the second occurs at ∼120 °C; both are attributed to water molecules. Interestingly, full decomposition did not occur for all compounds under these conditions, indicating high thermal stability. The dehydrated phases for compounds 2 and 3 are stable to ∼515 °C.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

The first weight loss occurs at ~180 °C and is attributed to coordinated water molecules. The structure of the dehydrated phase was determined (1d) and is stable up to ~440 °C, where a small weight loss occurs, after which decomposition of the material occurs at 740 °C. The second weight loss may involve the loss of the acidic proton. Compound 2 has one weight loss step before decomposition (515 °C) and occurs below 100 °C. It is attributed to loss of water molecules, and the resultant structure was determined (2d). Compound 3 has two weight losses before decomposition (515 °C). The first is below 100 °C and the second occurs at ~120 °C; both are attributed to water molecules. Interestingly, full decomposition did not occur for all compounds under these conditions, indicating high thermal stability. The dehydrated phases for compounds 2 and 3 are stable to ~515 °C.

elements.content: The textural properties of the materials have provided interesting insights into the structures (Figure ). The N2 adsorption isotherms indicate that compounds 2 and 3 have a type I isotherm suggesting uniform microporosity. Compound 2 was found to have the largest surface area (Table ), which is in contrast to general trends; an increase in the reaction temperature generally decreases porosity. The high temperature phase, 2, was found to have a larger surface area than the low temperature phase. The change in reaction solution from water for 2 to a water/acetone mixture for 3 resulted in a decrease in surface area; however, both were greater than 80% microporous. At 10–3 P/P o the volume is already at 75 and 46 mL/g respectively for compounds 1 and 2, after which there is a very shallow slope to ∼0.80 P/P o. This indicates that the pores were mostly full at very low P/P o, and the pore size must be less than 10 Å. The thermogravimetric analysis shows a one-step weight loss for compound 2 and a two-step weight loss for compound 3 below 250 °C, associated with loss of water. These data suggest that the pore structures are different for compounds 2 and 3.

The thermogravimetric analysis shows a one-step weight loss for compound 2 and a two-step weight loss for compound 3 below 250 °C, associated with loss of water. Aluminum biphenylenediphosphonates were also determined to be microporous materials, but their structures were not determined due to poor powder crystallinity. A reaction with anhydrous AlCl3 resulted in a porous aluminum biphenylenediphosphonate (S BET 167.8 m2/g) with both four- and six-coordinate aluminum atoms; however, the S BET values are larger for compounds 2 and 3. Conversely, the H2 uptake was larger for the aluminum biphenylenediphosphonate (∼0.8 wt % at 760 Torr) than for compound 2 (0.43 wt % at 810 Torr and 77 K) (). The differences in the textural properties indicate that different types of pores are formed.

elements.content: Additionally, on the basis of thermal gravimetric analysis (Figure ), all compounds lose water, a telling sign for porosity. However, a type III isotherm indicating a nonporous material was found for compound 1. The inorganic layer for 1 differs most from 2 and 3, where only a six-coordinate aluminum atom is present. The difference in surface area for compounds 1 and 2 can be explained by the change in the framework upon loss of water.

elements.content: Reversible dehydration behavior was found for all compounds, with only compound 1 having a stable dehydrated phase (1d). 27Al­{1H} and 31P­{1H} NMR studies were performed on the initial phase and the dehydrated phase for compound 1. In situ PXRD was used to study the dehydration process for compounds 2 and 3 where rehydration occurs rapidly upon exposure to air (Figure ). In situ PXRD diffractograms show a change in diffraction peak positions upon heating and a rapid conversion to the hydrated phase upon exposure to water for compounds 2 and 3. Upon loss of water for compound 2, a more dramatic shift in the diffraction peak positions is observed in the PXRD diffractogram, indicating a larger change in the structure.

In Situ X-ray Diffraction

Reversible dehydration behavior was found for all compounds, with only compound 1 having a stable dehydrated phase (1d). 27Al{1H} and 31P{1H} NMR studies were performed on the initial phase and the dehydrated phase for compound 1. In situ PXRD was used to study the dehydration process for compounds 2 and 3 where rehydration occurs rapidly upon exposure to air (Figure ). In situ PXRD diffractograms show a change in diffraction peak positions upon heating and a rapid conversion to the hydrated phase upon exposure to water for compounds 2 and 3. Upon loss of water for compound 2, a more dramatic shift in the diffraction peak positions is observed in the PXRD diffractogram, indicating a larger change in the structure.

elements.content: For compound 1, the original structure can be regenerated from the dehydrated phase either by rehydration of water through exposure to the atmosphere for several months or refluxing in water overnight. Rehydration is rapid for compound 2 reflected in a more porous structure and a less stable dehydrated phase than for compound 1. The dehydration behavior of these materials can be described by the parent structures. In both compounds, the aluminum atom has an octahedral geometry with one oxygen atom from a water molecule. A five-coordinate metal would be expected from the loss of water. The geometry of the aluminum atom would then be square pyramidal without rearrangement of the inorganic framework. The geometry of the aluminum atom was determined to be trigonal bipyramidal for compound 1d; therefore rearrangement of the inorganic framework occurred, reducing the free volume (Figure ). However, for compound 2d the aluminum atom has a distorted square pyramidal geometry (Figure ). The slight change in geometry resulted in a wider channel. The large channels allows for easier reabsorption of water molecules. The change in free volume and the coordinately unsaturated metal are believed to be the main influences on the stability of the dehydrated phases of 1 and 2.

elements.content: A dehydration behavior similar to that of compound 2 was determined for Al2(OH)2­(H2O)2­(O3PCH2CH2PO3), where the compound rehydrates upon exposure to air within 5 min. The inorganic layer differs from the structures reported here; however, a distorted square pyramidal geometry was determined for the dehydrated phase. The preference to adopt the trigonal bipyramidal geometry is restricted in both compound 2 and Al2(OH)2­(H2O)2­(O3PCH2CH2PO3) by the rigid lattice. The distorted square pyramidal geometry results in an uncoordinated metal site that rapidly reabsorbs water. The activity of the uncoordinated metal site increases due to the preference to obtain an octahedral geometry. Coordinately unsaturated metal sites are important in gas adsorption properties and catalysts. Lewis acidity has been shown in microporous solids with accessible metal sites, so compound 2 is expected to show catalytic activity.

Lewis acidity has been shown in microporous solids with accessible metal sites, so compound 2 is expected to show catalytic activity.

elements.content: Three new aluminum phenylenediphosphonates Al­(H2O)­(O3PC6H4PO3H) (1), Al4(H2O)2­(O3PC6H4PO3)3 (2), and Al­(O3PC6H4PO3)0.75­·2H2O (3)) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions using the same ligand and have strikingly different properties. All compounds exhibit reversible dehydration behavior. Compounds 2 and 3 rapidly reabsorb water, while readsorption was much slower for compound 1. The crystal structures of the hydrated and dehydrated phases were determined using PXRD data for compounds 1 and 2. The aluminum coordination changed from octahedral to distorted trigonal bipyramidal for compound 1 and to the less stable distorted square pyramidal geometry for compound 2 upon dehydration. The change in free volume and the geometry of the aluminum ions helps to understand the difference in rehydration rates and porosity. Compounds 2 and 3 were microporous, while compound 1 was found to be nonporous.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three new aluminum phenylenediphosphonates Al(H2O)(O3PC6H4PO3H) (1), Al4(H2O)2(O3PC6H4PO3)3 (2), and Al(O3PC6H4PO3)0.75⋅2H2O (3)) were prepared under hydrothermal conditions using the same ligand and have strikingly different properties. All compounds exhibit reversible dehydration behavior. Compounds 2 and 3 rapidly reabsorb water, while readsorption was much slower for compound 1. The crystal structures of the hydrated and dehydrated phases were determined using PXRD data for compounds 1 and 2. The aluminum coordination changed from octahedral to distorted trigonal bipyramidal for compound 1 and to the less stable distorted square pyramidal geometry for compound 2 upon dehydration. The change in free volume and the geometry of the aluminum ions helps to understand the difference in rehydration rates and porosity. Compounds 2 and 3 were microporous, while compound 1 was found to be nonporous.

elements.content: Synthesis, detailed Reitveld refinement, and complete characterization of compounds 1–3 including solid-state NMR, Rietveld refinement plots, X-ray diffraction powder patterns, hydrogen sorption and microprobe BSE imaging is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. The structures of compounds 1−2d were deposited in the Cambridge Structural Database and can be requested free of charge with CCDC 1023585-1023588.

The hydrothermal reaction was carried out with 4 mL of ddi water and 2.5 mL of conc. HCl, which was added to a 12 mL capacity PTFE-lined pressure vessel containing 0.111 g (1.42 mmol) of bayerite and 0.321 g (1.34 mmol) of H4PDPA. The sealed reaction vessel was then heated to 160 °C for 5 days. The resulting white powder was filtered, washed with ddi water and acetone, and then air-dried. Yield: 0.262 g. Elemental analysis (%) and microprobe Al/P ratio calc: C 25.73, H 2.52, P/Al ratio 2.00. Exp: C 25.6, H 2.5, P/Al ratio 1.99.

Synthesis of Al­(O<sub>3</sub>PC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>PO<sub>3</sub>H), (<bold>1d</bold>)

Dehydration of Al­(O3PC6H4PO3H)·H2O at 200 °C overnight results in Al­(O3PC6H4PO3H) quantitatively. Elemental analysis (%) and microprobe Al/P ratio Calc: C 27.50, H 1.92, P/Al ratio 2.00. Exp C 27.4, H 1.9, P/Al ratio 2.00.

Synthesis of Al<sub>4</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>­(O<sub>3</sub>PC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, (<bold>2</bold>)

AlCl3 (0.5684 g, 4.26 mmol) and H4PDPA (0.1681 g, 0.706 mmol) were placed in a 12 mL Telfon-lined autoclave and filled with ddi water (4 mL) and heated at 210 °C for 5 days. The white gel was washed with ∼200 mL of water and dried in an oven at 70 °C giving a white powder. Yield: 0.162 g. Elemental analysis (%) and microprobe Al/P ratio Calc: C 25.6, H 1.91 P/Al ratio 1.50 Exp: C 23.0, H 2.57 P/Al ratio 1.44.

Synthesis of Al<sub>4</sub>(O<sub>3</sub>PC<sub>6</sub>H<sub>4</sub>PO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2.84</sub>­(OH)<sub>0.64</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>, (<bold>3</bold>)

AlCl3 (0.5684 g, 4.26 mmol) and H4PDPA (0.1682 g, 0.707 mmol) were placed in a 12 mL Telfon-lined autoclave and filled with ddi water (2.5 mL)/acetone (1.5 mL) and heated at 210 °C for 5 days. The product was washed with ∼200 mL of water/acetone mixture and dried in an oven at 70 °C giving a white powder. Yield: 0.169 g. Elemental analysis (%) and microprobe Al/P ratio. Calc: C 23.9, H 2.36. P/Al ratio 1.42, Exp: C 22.0, H 2.91. P/Al ratio 1.42.

cln_elements.content:
The thermogravimetric analysis data differs for compounds 1–3 (Figure ). Compound 1 has a three-step weight loss. The first weight loss occurs at ∼180 °C and is attributed to coordinated water molecules. The structure of the dehydrated phase was determined (1d) and is stable up to ∼440 °C, where a small weight loss occurs, after which decomposition of the material occurs at 740 °C. The second weight loss may involve the loss of the acidic proton. Compound 2 has one weight loss step before decomposition (515 °C) and occurs below 100 °C. It is attributed to loss of water molecules, and the resultant structure was determined (2d). Compound 3 has two weight losses before decomposition (515 °C). The first is below 100 °C and the second occurs at ∼120 °C; both are attributed to water molecules. Interestingly, full decomposition did not occur for all compounds under these conditions, indicating high thermal stability. The dehydrated phases for compounds 2 and 3 are stable to ∼515 °C.

Textural Properties

The textural properties of the materials have provided interesting insights into the structures (Figure ). The N2 adsorption isotherms indicate that compounds 2 and 3 have a type I isotherm suggesting uniform microporosity. Compound 2 was found to have the largest surface area (Table ), which is in contrast to general trends; an increase in the reaction temperature generally decreases porosity. The high temperature phase, 2, was found to have a larger surface area than the low temperature phase. The change in reaction solution from water for 2 to a water/acetone mixture for 3 resulted in a decrease in surface area; however, both were greater than 80% microporous. At 10–3 P/P o the volume is already at 75 and 46 mL/g respectively for compounds 1 and 2, after which there is a very shallow slope to ∼0.80 P/P o. This indicates that the pores were mostly full at very low P/P o, and the pore size must be less than 10 Å. The thermogravimetric analysis shows a one-step weight loss for compound 2 and a two-step weight loss for compound 3 below 250 °C, associated with loss of water. These data suggest that the pore structures are different for compounds 2 and 3.

Aluminum biphenylenediphosphonates were also determined to be microporous materials, but their structures were not determined due to poor powder crystallinity. A reaction with anhydrous AlCl3 resulted in a porous aluminum biphenylenediphosphonate (S BET 167.8 m2/g) with both four- and six-coordinate aluminum atoms; however, the S BET values are larger for compounds 2 and 3. Conversely, the H2 uptake was larger for the aluminum biphenylenediphosphonate (∼0.8 wt % at 760 Torr) than for compound 2 (0.43 wt % at 810 Torr and 77 K) (). The differences in the textural properties indicate that different types of pores are formed.
